design_intent.player_goal: Build a defensible network by shrinking the attack surface, carving zones, enforcing access, and surviving noisy adversaries.

mastery_model.update: Mastery += 8 on first correct; +4 on repeat correct; -6 on wrong (floor 0).

missions.name: Map the Terrain
missions.goal: Attack surface, security zones, device placement, failure modes, and basic segmentation.

missions.name: Software-Defined Reality
missions.goal: SDN/SD-WAN/SASE and the Zero Trust worldview.

missions.name: Gatekeepers at Layer 2
missions.goal: NAC, 802.1X, and switch-level protections that stop "plug-and-pwn".

missions.name: Tunnels and Tradeoffs
missions.goal: VPN fundamentals, IPsec vs TLS VPNs, and full vs split tunneling decisions.

missions.name: Appliance Arsenal
missions.goal: Jump servers, load balancers, proxies, web filtering, DLP, IDS/IPS.

missions.name: Control, Visibility, and Deception
missions.goal: Firewalls, ACLs, deception tech, and security telemetry.

boss.name: Boss: The Noise Hydra
boss.premise: On-path tricks, DNS misdirection, credential replay, and DDoS chaos—spot the pattern and pick the right control.

question_bank.stem: In network security design, what does "attack surface" mean?
question_bank.explanation: Attack surface is the total set of exposed entry/exit points (interfaces, services, users, paths). The trap is narrowing it to just ports or internet-facing hosts—those are common parts, not the whole surface.

options.A: All vulnerabilities found in a single application
options.B: All points where an attacker could try to enter or extract data from a system/network
options.D: Only open TCP ports discovered by a scanner

question_bank.rationaleCorrect: Attack surface is the total set of exposed entry/exit points (interfaces, services, users, paths).
